Description: Pastoral landscape, record of painting in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York from the Liber Veritatis; in foreground herdsman, two figures riding a donkey, cattle and goats crossing a river, beyond at right a bridge, and in background buildings on a hilltop Pen and brown ink and brown wash
Curator's comments: See 1957,1214.6 for information on the Liber Veritatis. This drawing records a painting that Claude make for a patron in Lyon between 1646 and 1647. This painting is now in The Met (inv.no. 47.12; canvas, 106 x 135 cm; Roethlisberger 1986, no. 174). It numbers among a multitude of Pastoral landscapes that Claude produced across his career and which were visions of an Arcadia clearly inspired by the Roman Campagna. The present painting is believed to have formed a pendant to the contemporary Pastoral Landscape with the Flight into Egypt (see 1957,1214.116). The inscription on the verso of this latter drawing allows for an identification of the patron of the painting recorded on the present sheet as a M. Parasson. Lit: M. Roethlisberger, Claude Lorrain, The Paintings, London 1961, LV109, pp. 272–273; M. Roethlisberger, ‘Claude Lorrain. The Drawings’, Berkeley & Los Angeles, 1968, no. 631; M. Kitson, ‘Claude Lorrain: Liber Veritatis’, London 1978, no. 109; M. Roethlisberger, ‘Tout l'œuvre peint de Claude Lorrain’, Paris, 1986, no. 174
